III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was grabbed inappropriately by staff during an
altercation.
Investigation The complainant was contacted on 02/22/2024 and no additional
information was provided.
Youth A was interviewed on 02/20/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled the incident in
question. Youth A stated he was already upset that day for
reasons he could not recall, but this manifested in him throwing
items around the pod and attempting to break items. Youth A
stated there were staff present talking to him but he could not
recall who this was. He stated this was after he had been
attempting to break into locked doors in the open area of the pod
with any items he could. Youth A stated he eventually pushed
past a staff member through an open door to the control room and
was able to get his hands on the keys to the doors within the pod.
He believed those keys were sitting out on a table in the locked
control room. Youth A stated staff tried stopping him at this point
but he could not recall who this was. Youth A recalled destroying
property once he was inside of the control room. He believed he
left the control room and was able to get back in a second time as
well. Youth A stated he then chose to stop destroying property
and slid the keys back to a staff member that he could not recall.
Youth A stated no staff members put their hands on him during
this incident but, they were all attempting to redirect and de-
escalate him.
Youth B was interviewed on 02/20/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled the incident in
question involving Youth A. Youth B stated he came out of the
2

shower area to only have a staff member try to stop him from
moving into the common area. He could not recall who this was.
Youth B stated he moved past this staff member, and their
interaction was not physical. Youth B stated he saw Youth A
destroying property in the common area of the pod at this point,
and there was a staff member near him. Youth B could not recall
who this staff member was. Youth B recalled seeing Youth A
push past staff through an already open door to the control room
of the pod and Youth A then proceeded to destroy property in the
control room. Youth B stated he attempted to join Youth A. Youth
B recalled all the other youth in the pod were in their rooms at this
point. Youth B stated he was in the control room with Youth A
when Youth A stopped his escalated behavior, gave the keys back
to staff and exited the control room. Youth B stated he did not see
any staff members put their hands on Youth A during any portion
of this incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 02/20/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated he was called to the pod
to assist because Youth B was very upset. Staff 1 stated he
addressed Youth B when he entered the pod and there were no
other youth in the room other than Youth A and Youth B. Staff 1
stated Youth B began to destroy property in the pod, including
attempting to damage security cameras. Staff 1 recalled Youth A
and Youth B were able to get into the control room of the pod, but
he was not sure how this occurred. Staff 1 believed this could
have occurred because he and other staff members involved, that
he could not name, were trying to move large items from the open
area to the control room as a means of managing the environment
for Youth A and Youth B. Moving the large items would have
prevented the youth from attempting to damage those items or
hurting themselves. However, this allowed the youth to push into
the normally locked and off limits area. Staff 1 did recall Youth A
had the keys to the control room and gave them back to a staff
member upon de-escalating. Staff 1 stated a restraint attempt
was made with Youth A where he and Staff 2 attempted to hold
Youth A with arms hooked and all three of them standing. Staff 1
stated Youth A almost immediately dropped to the ground and
both he and Staff 2 released their arms and were able to stay
standing. Staff 1 stated this was the extent of any restraint
attempts in which he participated or witnessed during the incident.
After that, the youth were able to be verbally de-escalated and
they both stopped destroying property and were not in the control
room any longer.
3

Staff 2 was interviewed on 03/18/2024 over the phone. He stated
he was working with Youth A and Youth B as they both started to
destroy property on the pod on the day in question. Staff 2 stated
the youth were trying to get into locked areas of the pod and
eventually one of them hit a security camera mounted on the wall.
Staff 2 recalled Staff 1 attempting to move some items from out in
the open into the control room when Youth A pushed past him into
the normally locked and off limits area. Staff 2 recalled Youth A
was destroying property in the control room for a few minutes and
he and Staff 1 attempted to manage the environment without
having to attempt a restraint of him. Staff 2 stated Youth A
grabbed a set of keys off of a desk while in there, but eventually
gave them back to Staff 2. Staff 2 stated he was able to do this by
holding Youth A’s wrist and grabbing them out of his hand. Staff 2
recalled Youth A not struggling or resisting when he attempted
this. At this time both Youth A and Youth B were somewhat de-
escalated and the property damage to the control room ceased.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 03/18/2024 over the phone. He
stated that he was present when Youth A and Youth B began to
destroy property in the pod. He recalled Youth A was able to push
past other staff into the control room of the pod. Supervisor 1
stated the staff involved, which he could not specifically recall, had
their backs turned to Youth A but Youth A overpowered them and
pushed into the room without staff putting their hands on him. It
was at this point that Youth A grabbed a set of keys from a desk.
Supervisor 1 recalled Youth A and Youth B destroying property in
the control room for a few minutes only for them to stop on their
own accord and leave the room on their own accord. Supervisor 1
believed this occurred because Youth B told Youth A they could
be done, and Youth A followed Youth B’s direction. Supervisor 1
stated Youth B later asked if he could help with the cleanup of the
mess that was created.
Documents reviewed:
• Video footage of the incident in question was shared.
Youth A and Youth B can be seen attempting
unsuccessfully to open two separate locked doors within
the pod and staff address them without putting their hands
on the youth. Neither youth particularly escalated at this
point. Eventually Youth B can be seen throwing a chair up
at the security camera and hitting it, effectively ending the
available footage.
• An Incident Report dated 02/15/2024 was provided and
reviewed. This document provided consisted details with
youth and staff interviews, including Youth B damaging the
4

security camera, Youth A and Youth B gaining access to
the control room of the pod past Staff 1 and then destroying
property.
• Pictures of the damaged items in the pod and control room
were provided.
• Facility policy titled “The SJJS Behavior Management
System” was provided and reviewed. It is noted that “a
safe physical intervention shall be used only as a last
resort, after all other methods of non-physical intervention
have been exhausted.”
• Facility policy titled “Youth Supervision” was provided and
reviewed. Of note it described a policy that staff “shall
remain alert to items that could be used as weapons (e.g.
electrical cords and broomsticks) and place/store them in
locations where youth do not have access.”
• Training records for Staff 1 and Staff 2 were provided and
no concerns were noted.
• No discipline was noted for either Staff 1 or Staff 2.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was no evidence found that there was any form of
hitting or pushing of Youth A or Youth B during this incident. In
addition, there were no facility policies broken during the
management of the youth involved.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
